options.label: A
options.text: Donor renal vein anastomosed end to side to the external iliac vein

options.label: B
options.text: If the donor renal artery lacks a Carrel patch, it may preferable to anastomose the donor artery end to end to the recipient's internal iliac artery

options.label: C
options.text: Ureter is anastomosed to the bladder by the Lich-Gregoir technique

questions.explanation:
Solution:

None of the above All the above-given statements are true and are involved in kidney transplantation

Highyeild:

Kidney Transplantation : Indication : ESRD(End Stage Renal Disease) Chronic glomerulonephritis Diabetic nephropathy Hypertension Renal vascular disease Polycystic kidney disease Chronic pyelonephritis Obstructive uropathy Contraindications Absolute : Active malignant disease Active infection Unreconstructable peripheral vascular disease Severe cardiac or pulmonary disease Active intravenous drug abuse Significant psychosocial barriers that interfere with the patient’s ability to comply with a complex medical regimen Relative : Limited life expectancy History of nonadherence to medication regimen History of noncompliance with dialysis Financial barriers Psychiatric issues Renal disease with a high recurrence rate Morbid obesity (BMI is centre dependent) Frailty Transplant Surgery : Preparation of the donor's kidney Surgery A curved incision is made in the lower abdomen and, after dividing the muscles of the abdominal wall, the peritoneum is swept upwards and medially to expose the iliac vessels. These are dissected free so that they can be controlled with vascular clamps. The kidney is then removed from the ice and the donor renal vein is anastomosed end to side to the external iliac vein. The donor renal artery on a Carrel patch of the donor aorta is anastomosed end to side to the external iliac artery. If the donor renal artery lacks an aortic patch, as in the case of a living-donor transplant, it may be preferable to anastomose the donor artery end to end to the recipient's internal iliac artery. The ureter, which is kept reasonably short to avoid the risk of distal ischaemia, is then anastomosed to the bladder by direct implantation of the ureter into the dome of the bladder with a mucosa-to-mucosa anastomosis, followed by the closure of the muscular wall of the bladder over the ureter to create a short tunnel , the Lich–Gregoir technique. Early Postoperative Care DGF(Delayed renal Allograft Function) - the need for dialysis in the first 7 days post-transplant Surgical Complications : Haemorrhage Renal Artery Thrombosis Renal Vein Thrombosis Urological Complications Urinary Leak Ureteric Obstruction Lymphocele Transplant Renal Artery Stenosis (TRAS) Renal Allograft Dysfunction

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. The kidney is then removed from the ice and the donor renal vein is anastomosed end to side to the external iliac vein. Option: B. The donor renal artery on a Carrel patch of the donor aorta is anastomosed end to side to the external iliac artery. If the donor renal artery lacks an aortic patch, as in the case of a living-donor transplant, it may be preferable to anastomose the donor artery end to end to the recipient's internal iliac artery. Option: C. The ureter, which is kept reasonably short to avoid the risk of distal ischaemia, is then anastomosed to the bladder by direct implantation of the ureter into the dome of the bladder with a mucosa-to-mucosa anastomosis, followed by the closure of the muscular wall of the bladder over the ureter to create a short tunnel, the Lich–Gregoir technique.

Extraedge:

Immunosuppression for renal transplantation generally comprises induction therapy with the anti-CD25 monoclonal antibody basiliximab followed by a maintenance regimen of a calcineurin inhibitor (most usually tacrolimus), an antiproliferative agent (usually mycophenolic acid) and corticosteroid (prednisolone). The anti-CD52 monoclonal antibody alemtuzumab can be used for induction instead of basiliximab patients at high risk of allograft rejection or as part of a steroid avoidance strategy in patients at high risk of developing diabetes post transplantation

questions.text: The most common indication for liver transplantation in children is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Biliary atresia In children, who account for around 10–15% of all liver transplantations, 'biliary atresia' is the most common indication for transplantation.

Random:

Types of LT (based on source of liver allograft) DDLT, which includes DBD (70–80%) and DCD (20–30%) LDLT – this can be adult to adult or adult to child Split and reduced-size LT ECDs Auxiliary LT Domino LT Paired-exchange programme

questions.text: Order of anastomosis in Lung transplant is: Pulmonary vein Bronchus Pulmonary artery Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1>2>3 During lung transplantation, the donor pulmonary veins on a left atrial cuff are anastomosed to the recipient's left atrium. Next, the bronchial anastomosis and the pulmonary arterial anastomosis are completed.

Highyeild:

Single-lung transplantation is performed through a posterolateral thoracotomy and double-lung transplantation through a bilateral thoracotomy or median sternotomy. Cardio-Pulmonary bypass is usually required if pulmonary hypertension is present. Indications : Cases where retention of the other lung will not pose a risk of infection, such as fibrotic lung disease or emphysema. Using this option in cystic fibrosis, for example, would be contraindicated. Single-lung transplantation is associated with inferior survival.

questions.text: Criteria for Brainstem death include all EXCEPT:
questions.correct_answer: C. Absence of Deep tendon reflexes
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Absence of Deep tendon reflexes

Highyeild:

Brainstem Death Definition: Permanent loss of the capacity for consciousness and spontaneous breathing Brainstem death occurs after severe brain injury as a result of either trauma or a cerebrovascular accident Conditions to be excluded before testing : hypothermia, muscle relaxants, drugs with central nervous system depressive effects, alcohol intoxication, Hypothyroidism, uraemic encephalopathy, hepatic encephalopathy, hypoglycaemia hyponatraemia Clinical Testing for Brainstem Death : Absence of Cranial Reflexes Absence of Cranial Nerve Motor Response Absence of Spontaneous Respiration

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Options: A, B & D. All the other options are part of clinical testing for brainstem death.

questions.text: The model for End-Stage Liver Disease score is based on:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above All the above options are part of the MELD model of assessment.

Highyeild:

The MELD score was originally developed to predict short-term prognosis in patients undergoing trans-jugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt insertion but has now been adopted to prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation. In the MELD model, the survival probability of patients with end-stage liver disease is computed based on the patient’s International normalized ratio (INR), Serum bilirubin, Serum creatinine. MELD scores correlate with operative mortality: 1% increase for each MELD point up to 20 and a further 2% for each point above 20 , with rates considerably higher following emergency presentation MELD Score > 35 should be considered for transplant very soon

Extraedge:

Types of LT (based on source of liver allograft) DDLT, which includes DBD (70–80%) and DCD (20–30%) LDLT – this can be adult to adult or adult to child Split and reduced-size LT ECDs Auxiliary LT Domino LT Paired-exchange programme

questions.text: Most important HLA for organ transplantation and tissue typing:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

HLA-DR HLA matching has a relatively small but definite beneficial effect on allograft survival. (HLA- DR> HLA-B> HLA- A) HLA-DR is the most important of all.

Highyeild:

Allograft rejection is directed against human leukocyte antigens (HLAs) . These are a group of cell surface glycoprotein molecules. HLA molecules are divided into class I (A, B and C) and class II (DR, DP and DQ). Class I molecules are expressed on the surface of all nucleated cells, but class II are only expressed by antigen-presenting cells (APCs) such as dendritic cells and B lymphocytes. HLA molecules are encoded in the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) on chromosome 6 . They are highly polymorphic , i.e. their amino acid sequences differ widely between individuals. To give an example, there are >1000 variants of the HLA-B gene. The antigens at HLA-A, -B and -DR are together described as the tissue type. The level of mismatch between the HLA molecules determines the strength of the immune response. Every individual has two copies of each HLA gene and so for each locus (A, B or DR) it is possible to have 0, 1 or 2 mismatched genes. As the number of mismatches increases so does the chance of immune recognition and rejection . The best-matched grafts are described as having a mismatch of 0–0–0 , i.e. no mismatches at A, B or DR, respectively. A completely mismatched graft would be annotated as a 2–2–2 mismatch. DR mismatches have a more powerful effect than B mismatches, and A mismatches are the least important.

questions.text: HLA matching is not necessary for which of the following transplantation:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Liver HLA matching is not done for: Heart Liver Cornea Patients awaiting heart transplantation are also screened for the presence of HLA antibodies and those with preformed antibodies are subjected to a prospective cross-match test. Although heart allografts rarely undergo hyperacute rejection, transplantation in the presence of a positive cross-match is associated with graft loss from accelerated acute rejection. Even in the presence of a strongly positive crossmatch test, liver transplants rarely undergo hyperacute rejection, although long-term survival is reduced.

Highyeild:

Allograft rejection is directed against human leukocyte antigens (HLAs) . These are a group of cell surface glycoprotein molecules. HLA molecules are divided into class I (A, B and C) and class II (DR, DP and DQ). Class I molecules are expressed on the surface of all nucleated cells, but class II are only expressed by antigen-presenting cells (APCs) such as dendritic cells and B lymphocytes. HLA molecules are encoded in the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) on chromosome 6 . They are highly polymorphic , i.e. their amino acid sequences differ widely between individuals. To give an example, there are >1000 variants of the HLA-B gene. The antigens at HLA-A, -B and -DR are together described as the tissue type. The level of mismatch between the HLA molecules determines the strength of the immune response. Every individual has two copies of each HLA gene and so for each locus (A, B or DR) it is possible to have 0, 1 or 2 mismatched genes. As the number of mismatches increases so does the chance of immune recognition and rejection . The best-matched grafts are described as having a mismatch of 0–0–0 , i.e. no mismatches at A, B or DR, respectively. A completely mismatched graft would be annotated as a 2–2–2 mismatch. DR mismatches have a more powerful effect than B mismatches, and A mismatches are the least important.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Options B, C & D : If, when considering renal, pancreas or bone marrow transplantation, the crossmatch test is strongly positive, transplantation should not proceed, or hyperacute rejection is likely.

questions.text: Alemtuzumab is a monoclonal antibody against
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anti- CD 52 Anti-CD52 mAb:(Alemtuzumab) Depletion of lymphocytes.

Highyeild:

Immunosuppressive Agents : MOA: Depend on anti-inflammatory effects and the prevention of lymphocyte activation and proliferation Two Phases : Induction Phase : Combination of high-dose intravenous steroids and the anti-CD25 monoclonal antibody basiliximab, which blocks IL-2 receptors In High-Risk Cases, ATG and the monoclonal antibody alemtuzumab Maintenance Phase: Triple therapy with a calcineurin inhibitor (ciclosporin or tacrolimus), an antiproliferative agent (azathioprine or mycophenolic acid) and steroids A range of different immunosuppressive agents is available that act at different sites during T-cell activation to prevent rejection. Corticosteroids: Widespread anti-inflammatory effects Azathioprine: Prevents lymphocyte proliferation Mycophenolic acid: Prevents lymphocyte proliferation Calcineurin inhibitors:(ciclosporin/tacrolimus) Blocks IL-2 gene transcription mTOR inhibitors: Blocks IL-2 receptor signal transduction ALG Depletion and blockade of lymphocytes Anti-CD25 mAb:(Basiliximab) Targets activated T cells Anti-CD52 mAb:(Alemtuzumab) Depletion of lymphocytes Anti-CD20 mAb:(Rituximab) Depletion of B lymphocytes CTLA-4Ig:(Belatacept) Blocks T-cell co-stimulation

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Anti-CD20 mAb:(Rituximab) Depletion of B lymphocytes Option: C. Anti-CD25 mAb:(Basiliximab) Targets activated T cells

questions.text: Which one of the following is a specific - complication of enteric drainage?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

None of the above

Highyeild:

Pancreas Transplantation: The pancreas graft is placed intraperitoneally in the pelvis, usually on the right, and the kidney graft is placed on the left side. The donor vessels of the pancreas graft are anastomosed to the recipient iliac vessels and the exocrine secretions are most commonly dealt with by anastomosing the graft duodenum to the small bowel (enteric drainage) often via a Roux-en-Y loop, although the duodenum may sometimes be anastomosed to the bladder (urinary drainage) The bladder-drained pancreas can cause cystitis from pancreatic enzyme secretion and electrolyte disturbance, acidosis and dehydration from the loss of bicarbonate. Up to 50% of patients with bladder-drained pancreas transplants require enteric conversion (where the transplant duodenum is surgically detached from the bladder and reconnected to the small bowel) within the first year following the transplant. This usually follows recurrent hospital admissions for acidosis and is performed to mitigate the risk of acute kidney injury. Also, the indication for conversion may be driven by patient choice because of symptoms from chemical cystitis, urinary tract infection (UTI) and the need for high-dose oral sodium bicarbonate. Late complications of pancreas transplantation include pseudoaneurysm formation, which may result from fungal infection or a vascular anastomosis, and highlights the importance of culturing the preservation fluid at the time of transplant and treating any cultured microorganisms

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Options: A & B. Bladder-drained pancreases can cause cystitis from pancreatic enzyme secretion and electrolyte disturbance, acidosis and dehydration from the loss of bicarbonate Option: C. Generic Complication

Solution:

Liver transplant

Highyeild:

Domino LT involves transplanting a liver from a patient with metabolic disease who needs LT into a patient with end-stage liver disease with the expectation that the recipient will not develop the metabolic syndrome or the recurrent syndrome will have minimal effect . Advantages : Several hereditary metabolic diseases such as familial amyloid polyneuropathy (FAP), maple syrup urine disease and familial hypercholesterolaemia are caused by aberrant or deficient protein production in the liver, and these conditions can be cured with an orthotopic LT. Although their native livers eventually caused severe systemic disease in these patients, these livers are otherwise structurally and functionally normal, and hence used as domino for those with end-stage liver failure. Even if they develop amyloidosis, it would take 10–20 years for the disease to become symptomatic in these recipients. If they have no recurrence of the tumour and become symptomatic from FAP in the future they can be offered a retransplant without the risk of recurrence of malignancy. Example: Domino LT is the use of a liver from a patient with FAP to a patient who is outside transplant criteria for liver malignancy.

Extraedge:

Types of LT (based on source of liver allograft) DDLT, which includes DBD (70–80%) and DCD (20–30%) LDLT – this can be adult to adult or adult to child Split and reduced-size LT ECDs Auxiliary LT Domino LT Paired-exchange programme

questions.text: True about causes of early allograft dysfunction in kidney transplantation are all Except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Arterial stenosis

Highyeild:

Acute Renal Allograft Dysfunction : This can be defined as a rise in serum creatinine of >10% from baseline or an absolute rise of ≥20 µmol/L. Allograft dysfunction should be investigated by urinalysis and culture to exclude urinary tract infection, CNI blood levels for drug-mediated nephrotoxicity and Doppler ultrasound scanning to check for arterial perfusion, venous drainage and hydronephrosis due to urinary obstruction. If there is uncertainty about the cause of graft dysfunction, a percutaneous needle-core transplant biopsy should be performed to establish whether allograft rejection is present. Long-term Allograft Dysfunction : Immunological : The commonest cause of long-term renal allograft damage and subsequent loss is chronic AMR. This is often related to inadequate compliance with immunosuppressive medication. There is no proven treatment for chronic AMR. Non - Immunological: Irreversible and leads to transplant failure Factors in maintaining good long-term allograft function Meticulous adherence to immunosuppressive medication Good blood pressure control (<130/80 mmHg).

options.label: A
options.text: A graft performed between different individual

options.label: B
options.text: A graft performed between different species

options.label: C
options.text: A graft placed in a normal anatomical site

options.label: D
options.text: A graft placed in a site different from that where the organ is normally located

questions.correct_answer: C. A graft placed in a normal anatomical site
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A graft placed in a normal anatomical site Orthotopic graft: a graft placed in its normal anatomical site.

Highyeild:

Allograft: an organ or tissue transplanted from one individual to another Alloantigen: transplant antigen Alloantibody: transplant antibodies HLA: human leukocyte antigen, the main trigger to graft rejection Xenograft: a graft performed between different species Orthotopic graft: a graft placed in its normal anatomical site Example: APOLT (Auxiliary Partial Orthotopic Liver Transplantation) for acute liver failure Heterotopic graft: a graft placed in a site different from that where the organ is normally located.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Allograft: an organ or tissue transplanted from one individual to another Option: B. Xenograft: a graft performed between different species Option: D. Heterotopic graft: a graft placed in a site different from that where the organ is normally located.

Extraedge:

Causes of early graft dysfunction Any rise in serum creatinine of >10% of baseline or ≥20 μmol/L should be considered as acute allograft dysfunction that requires investigation. Possible causes are: Acute rejection (antibody mediated or cell mediated) Calcineurin inhibitor toxicity Dehydration Urinary tract infection or pyelonephritis Any other source of sepsis Renal vein or renal artery thrombosis Ureteric obstruction or urine leak Causes of long-term graft dysfunction Immunological Chronic AMR Acute CMR or AMR, which can occur at any time Non-immunological Pre-existing damage in the donor kidney (especially relevant to DCD and extended criteria donor kidneys) Early ischaemia-reperfusion injury Chronic calcineurin nephrotoxicity Ureteric or bladder outflow obstruction Recurrent urinary tract infection or pyelonephritis BK polyomavirus nephropathy Recurrent native disease: glomerulonephritis; focal segmental glomerulosclerosis; immunoglobulin A nephropathy Renal artery stenosis Poorly controlled hypertension Dyslipidaemia

questions.text: Transplant rejection occurs during the first 6 months. What type of graft rejection does it refer to?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Acute rejection Acute allograft rejection usually occurs during the first 6 months.

Highyeild:

Types of allograft rejection Hyperacute rejection: Immediate graft destruction due to ABO or preformed anti-HLA antibodies. Characterized by intravascular thrombosis and interstitial haemorrhage. Acute rejection: Usually occurs during the first 6 months T-cell dependent Cell-mediated(Acute Cell-Mediated Rejection - CMR) (10-20%) Mediated by Direct Antigen presentation Characteristic Biopsy Finding: Lymphocytic Infiltration Treatment : High-dose pulsed intravenous steroids (methylprednisolone 0.5 g intravenously for 3 days) Lymphocyte-depleting intravenous antithymocyte globulin (ATG) - in steroid-resistant rejection Antibody-mediated (Acute Antibody-Mediated Rejection - AMR ) (<5%) Caused by HLA DSA Biopsy Finding: Inflammation of the vessels (vasculitis) and deposition of the complement component C4d in the peritubular capillaries Treatment: Plasma exchange and Rituximab Chronic Antibody - Mediated rejection: Occurs after first 6 months The most common cause of graft failure Antibodies play an important role

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Immediate graft destruction due to ABO or preformed anti-HLA antibodies Option: C. Occurs after the first 6 months

Extraedge:

Causes of early graft dysfunction Any rise in serum creatinine of >10% of baseline or ≥20 μmol/L should be considered as acute allograft dysfunction that requires investigation. Possible causes are: Acute rejection (antibody mediated or cell mediated) Calcineurin inhibitor toxicity Dehydration Urinary tract infection or pyelonephritis Any other source of sepsis Renal vein or renal artery thrombosis Ureteric obstruction or urine leak Causes of long-term graft dysfunction Immunological Chronic AMR Acute CMR or AMR, which can occur at any time Non-immunological Pre-existing damage in the donor kidney (especially relevant to DCD and extended criteria donor kidneys) Early ischaemia-reperfusion injury Chronic calcineurin nephrotoxicity Ureteric or bladder outflow obstruction Recurrent urinary tract infection or pyelonephritis BK polyomavirus nephropathy Recurrent native disease: glomerulonephritis; focal segmental glomerulosclerosis; immunoglobulin A nephropathy Renal artery stenosis Poorly controlled hypertension Dyslipidaemia

questions.text: Controlled donors belong to which Category group according to Maastricht Classification?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

3,4

Highyeild:

Organs may be obtained from living donors or deceased donors (DD). DD may be either brain-stem dead, heart-beating donors (donation after brain death or DBD donors) or donation after circulatory death (DCD) donors. Donation after circulatory death describes the recovery of organs for transplantation after death confirmed by circulatory criteria. These donors were formerly called asystolic or non-heart-beating donors In DCD donors cardiorespiratory arrest occurs prior to starting organ retrieval. The organs are therefore warm but not being perfused with oxygenated blood for a period of time before they are flushed with cold preservation solution. This warm ischaemia period should be limited as much as possible Types : Controlled DCD : Donation after death resulting from the planned withdrawal of life-sustaining cardiorespiratory support is called controlled DCD. Suffered massive and irreversible cerebral damage but have an intact brainstem and so they are self-ventilating The warm Ischaemic Period is 10 mins Uncontrolled DCD : Organ donation after unexpected and irreversible cardiac arrest is referred to as uncontrolled DCD Suffered an unexpected and irrecoverable cardiac event either outside or inside the hospital The warm Ischaemic Period is 45 mins Modified Maastricht classification of donation after circulatory death (DCD). Category Description Type of DCD Location I Dead on arrival at hospital Uncontrolled ED I I Unsuccessful resuscitation after cardiac arrest Uncontrolled ED I I I Anticipated cardiac arrest after withdrawal of support Controlled ICU IV Cardiac arrest in brain- dead donor Controlled ICU V Unexpected cardiac arrest in ICU Uncontrolled ICU ED, emergency department; ICU, intensive care unit.

questions.text: The Gold Standard preservative solution for Static cold storage is:
questions.correct_answer: A. The University of Wisconsin Solution
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The University of Wisconsin Solution Commonly used preservation solutions include the University of Wisconsin (UW) solution: They all contain impermeant to limit cell swelling, buffers to counter acidosis and electrolytes, the composition of which reflects that of intracellular rather than extracellular fluid. UW solution is particularly effective for liver grafts, and after perfusion with UW solution, the liver can be stored safely for up to 24 hours.

Highyeild:

Static Cold Storage Static cold storage (SCS) has remained the gold standard preservation method for the pancreas graft since the first transplantation was performed in 1966. Principle: Hypothermic Preservation Flushing of Organs : Effects : it flushes blood out of the microcirculation to prevent thrombosis it cools the organs to a temperature of <5°C and so reduces tissue oxygen requirements it replaces the normal extracellular fluid with the preservation fluid Advantages : Simplicity Relative Effectiveness Low Cost Preservation Solution: UW Solution - the gold standard Has 3 Components: electrolytes, an impermeant and a buffer

questions.text: The optimum Cold ischemic time for a Small Intestine transplant is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

< 4 hrs Optimal cold storage times (approximate): Kidney: < 18 hrs Liver: < 12 hrs Pancreas: < 10 hrs Small intestine: < 4 hrs Heart: < 3 hrs Lung: < 3 hrs

Highyeild:

An important aspect of donor selection is cold ischemia time. Compared to other abdominal organs, intestinal allografts are particularly sensitive to cold ischemia owing to the highly vascularized and metabolically active mucosa. Prolonged cold storage of the graft may lead to loss of mucosal integrity , and thus, bacterial translocation or intestinal perforation early after implantation; therefore, many protocols advise a maximum cold ischemia time of 6 to 8 hours. As a result, optimal small bowel donors are hemodynamically stable, require minimal vasopressor support, and are geographically close to the recipient transplant centre.

Extraedge:

Causes of early graft dysfunction Any rise in serum creatinine of >10% of baseline or ≥20 μmol/L should be considered as acute allograft dysfunction that requires investigation. Possible causes are: Acute rejection (antibody mediated or cell mediated) Calcineurin inhibitor toxicity Dehydration Urinary tract infection or pyelonephritis Any other source of sepsis Renal vein or renal artery thrombosis Ureteric obstruction or urine leak Causes of long-term graft dysfunction Immunological Chronic AMR Acute CMR or AMR, which can occur at any time Non-immunological Pre-existing damage in the donor kidney (especially relevant to DCD and extended criteria donor kidneys) Early ischaemia-reperfusion injury Chronic calcineurin nephrotoxicity Ureteric or bladder outflow obstruction Recurrent urinary tract infection or pyelonephritis BK polyomavirus nephropathy Recurrent native disease: glomerulonephritis; focal segmental glomerulosclerosis; immunoglobulin A nephropathy Renal artery stenosis Poorly controlled hypertension Dyslipidaemia
